title: Probiotic
description: Probiotic Probiotics are dietary supplements containing potentially beneficial bacteria or yeasts. According to the currently adopted definition by FAO/WHO,
cleaned_text: | | Probiotics are dietary supplements containing potentially beneficial [bacteria](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Bacteria.html) or [yeasts](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Yeast.html). According to the currently adopted definition by FAO/ [WHO](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/World_health_organization.html), probiotics are: 'Live microorganisms which when administered in adequate amounts confer a health benefit on the host'. [[1]](#_note-FAO.2FWHO/) [Lactic acid bacteria](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactic_acid_bacteria.html) (LAB) are the most common type of [microbes](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Microbes.html) used. LAB have been used in the food industry for many years, because they are able to convert sugars (including [lactose](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactose.html)) and other [carbohydrates](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Carbohydrates.html) into [lactic acid](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactic_acid.html). This not only provides the characteristic sour taste of [fermented](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Fermentation_%28food%29.html) dairy foods such as yogurt, but also by lowering the pH may create fewer opportunities for spoilage organisms to grow, hence creating huge health benefits on preventing [gastrointestinal infections](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Digestive_disease.html). [[2]](#_note-pap/). Strains of the genera [Lactobacillus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactobacillus.html) and the most widely used probiotic bacteria. [[3]](#_note-Tannock/) Probiotic bacterial cultures are intended to assist the body's naturally occurring [gut flora](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Gut_flora.html) to reestablish themselves. They are sometimes recommended by doctors, and, more frequently, by nutritionists, after a course of [antibiotics](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Antibiotics.html), or as part of the treatment for gut related [candidiasis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Candidiasis.html). Claims are made that probiotics strengthen the [immune system](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Immune_system.html) to combat [allergies](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Allergies.html) and other immunal diseases [[2]](#_note-pap/), [[4]](#_note-Sanders/). The rationale for probiotics is that the body contains a miniature ecology of [microbes](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Microbe.html), collectively known as the [gut flora](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Gut_flora.html). A number of bacterial types are thought to be thrown out of balance by a wide range of circumstances including the use of [antibiotics](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Antibiotics.html) or other drugs, excess alcohol, stress, disease, or exposure to [toxic](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Toxic.html) substances. In cases like these, the bacteria that work well with our bodies (see [symbiosis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Symbiosis.html)) may decrease in number, an event which allows harmful competitors to thrive, to the detriment of our health. Maintenance of a healthy gut flora is, however, dependent on many factors, especially the quality of food intake. Including a significant proportion of [prebiotic](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Prebiotic_%28nutrition%29.html) foods in the diet has been demonstrated[citation needed] to support a healthy gut flora and may be another means of achieving the desirable health benefits promised by probiotics. Additional recommended knowledge History of probiotics Probiotics, which means "for life", have been used for centuries as natural components in health-promoting foods. The original observation of the positive role played by certain bacteria was first introduced by Russian scientist and Nobel laureate [Eli Metchnikoff](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Eli_Metchnikoff.html), who in the beginning of the 20th century suggested that it would be possible to modify the [gut flora](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Gut_flora.html) and to replace harmful microbes by useful microbes. [[5]](#_note-0/) Metchnikoff, at that time a professor at the [Pasteur Institute](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Pasteur_Institute.html) in Paris, produced the notion that the ageing process results from the activity of putrefactive (proteolytic) [microbes](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Microbe.html) producing toxic substances in the [large bowel](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Large_bowel.html). Proteolytic bacteria such as clostridia, which are part of the normal gut flora, produce toxic substances including [phenols](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Phenols.html), indols and [ammonia](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Ammonia.html) from the [digestion](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Digestion.html) of [proteins](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Proteins.html). According to Metchnikoff these compounds were responsible for what he called "intestinal auto-intoxication", which caused the physical changes associated with old age. It was at that time known that milk fermented with lactic-acid bacteria inhibits the growth of proteolytic bacteria because of the low pH produced by the fermentation of [lactose](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactose.html). Metchnikoff had also observed that certain rural populations in Europe, for example in Bulgaria and the Russian Steppes who lived largely on milk fermented by lactic-acid bacteria were exceptionally long lived. Based on these facts, Metchnikoff proposed that consumption of fermented milk would "seed" the [intestine](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Intestine.html) with harmless lactic-acid bacteria and decrease the intestinal pH and that this would suppress the growth of proteolytic bacteria. Metchnikoff himself introduced in his diet sour milk fermented with the bacteria he called "Bulgarian Bacillus" and found his health benefited. Friends in Paris soon followed his example and physicians began prescribing the sour milk diet for their patients. [[6]](#_note-1/) Henry Tissier, also from the Pasteur Institute, was the first to isolate a Bifidobacterium. He isolated the bacterium from a breast-fed infant and named it Bacillus bifidus communis. [[7]](#_note-Tissier/) This bacterium was later renamed Bifidobacterium bifidum. Tissier showed that bifidobacteria are predominant in the gut flora of breast-fed babies, and he recommended administration of bifidobacteria to infants suffering from [diarrhea](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Diarrhea.html). The mechanism claimed was that bifidobacteria would displace the proteolytic bacteria that cause the disease. German professor Alfred Nissle, in 1917 isolated a strain of [Escherichia coli](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Escherichia_coli.html) from the [feces](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Feces.html) of a First World War soldier who did not develop [enterocolitis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Enterocolitis.html) during a severe outbreak of shigellosis. [[8]](#_note-2/) In those days, [antibiotics](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Antibiotics.html) were not yet discovered, and Nissle used the strain with considerable success in acute cases of infectious intestinal diseases ( [salmonellosis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Salmonellosis.html) and shigellosis). Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 is still in use and is one of the few examples of a non-LAB probiotic. In 1920 called [Lactobacillus bulgaricus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactobacillus_bulgaricus.html), could not live in the human intestine [[9]](#_note-3/), and the fermented food phenomena petered out. Metchnikoff's theory was disputable (at this stage), and people doubted his theory of longevity. After Metchnikoff's death in 1916, the centre of activity moved to the US. It was reasoned that bacteria originating from the gut were more likely to produce the desired effect in the gut, and in 1935 certain strains of [Lactobacillus acidophilus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactobacillus_acidophilus.html) were found to be very active when implanted in the human digestive tract. [[10]](#_note-4/) Trials were carried out using this organism, and encouraging results were obtained especially in the relief of chronic [constipation](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Constipation.html). The term "probiotics" was first introduced in 1965 by Lilly and Stillwell, when it was described as growth promoting factors produced by microorganisms ( [protozoa](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Protozoa.html)). [[11]](#_note-5/)Contrasting antibiotics, probiotics were defined as microbially derived factors that stimulate the growth of other microorganisms. In 1989 Roy Fuller suggested a definition of probiotics which has been widely used: "A live microbial feed supplement which beneficially affects the host animal by improving its intestinal microbial balance". [[12]](#_note-6/) Fuller's definition emphasizes the requirement of viability for probiotics and introduces the aspect of a beneficial effect on the host. In the 1960s the dairy industry began to promote fermented milk products containing Lactobacillus acidophilus.[citation needed] In subsequent decades other Lactobacillus species have been introduced including [Lactobacillus rhamnosus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactobacillus_rhamnosus.html), Lactobacillus casei, and Lactobacillus johnsonii, because they are intestinal species with beneficial properties. [[13]](#_note-7/) Effects There is no published evidence that probiotic supplements are able to completely replace the body's natural flora when these have been killed off; indeed bacterial levels in faeces disappear within days when supplementation ceases [[14]](#_note-8/). Potential benefits Experiments into the benefits of probiotic therapies suggest a range of potentially beneficial medicinal uses for probiotics. For many of the potential benefits, research is limited and only preliminary results are available. It should be noted that the effects described are not general effects of probiotics. All effects can only be attributed to the strain(s) tested, not to the species, nor to the whole group of LAB (or other probiotics). Managing Lactose Intolerance As lactic acid bacteria actively convert [lactose](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactose.html) into [lactic acid](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactic_acid.html), ingestion of certain active strains may help lactose intolerant individuals tolerate more lactose than what they would have otherwise. [[4]](#_note-Sanders/) In practice probiotics are not specifically targeted for this purpose, as most are relatively low in lactase activity as compared to the normal yogurt bacteria. Prevention of Colon Cancer In laboratory investigations, some strains of LAB have demonstrated anti-mutagenic effects thought to be due to their ability to bind with heterocyclic amines; [carcinogenic](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Carcinogenic.html) substances formed in cooked meat. [[15]](#_note-Wollowski/) Animal studies have demonstrated that some LAB can protect against colon cancer in rodents, though human data is limited and conflicting. [[16]](#_note-Brady/) Most human trials have found that the strains tested may exert anti- [carcinogenic](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Carcinogenic.html) effects by decreasing the activity of an enzyme called -glucuronidase [[16]](#_note-Brady/) (which can generate carcinogens in the digestive system). Lower rates of colon cancer among higher consumers of fermented dairy products have been observed in some population studies. [[4]](#_note-Sanders/) Cholesterol Lowering Animal studies have demonstrated the efficacy of a range of LAB to be able to lower serum [cholesterol](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Cholesterol.html) levels, presumably by breaking down [bile](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Bile.html) in the gut, thus inhibiting its reabsorption (which enters the blood as cholesterol). Some, but not all human trials have shown that dairy foods fermented with specific LAB can produce modest reductions in total and LDL cholesterol levels in those with normal levels to begin with, however trials in hyperlipidemic subjects are needed. [[4]](#_note-Sanders/) Lowering Blood Pressure Several small clinical trials have shown that consumption of milk fermented with various strains of LAB can result in modest reductions in [blood pressure](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Blood_pressure.html). It is thought that this is due to the [ACE inhibitor](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/ACE_inhibitor.html)-like [peptides](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Peptides.html) produced during fermentation. [[4]](#_note-Sanders/) Improving Immune Function and Preventing Infections LAB are thought to have several presumably beneficial effects on immune function. They may protect against [pathogens](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Pathogens.html) by means of [competitive inhibition](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Competitive_inhibition.html) (i.e., by competing for growth) and there is evidence to suggest that they may improve immune function by increasing the number of [IgA](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/IgA.html)-producing plasma cells, increasing or improving [phagocytosis](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Phagocytosis.html) as well as increasing the proportion of [T lymphocytes](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/T_lymphocytes.html) and Natural Killer cells. [[17]](#_note-Reid_Jass_Sebulsky/) [[18]](#_note-Ouwehand_Salminen_Isolauri/) Clinical trials have demonstrated that probiotics may decrease the incidence of respiratory tract infections [[19]](#_note-9/) and [dental caries](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Dental_caries.html) in children [[20]](#_note-10/) . LAB foods and supplements have been shown to be effective in the treatment and prevention of acute [diarrhea](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Diarrhea.html); decreasing the severity and duration of [rotavirus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Rotavirus.html) infections in children as well as travelers diarrhea in adults. [[17]](#_note-Reid_Jass_Sebulsky/) [[18]](#_note-Ouwehand_Salminen_Isolauri/) Helicobacter pylori LAB are also thought to aid in the treatment of [Helicobacter pylori](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Helicobacter_pylori.html) infections (which cause [peptic ulcers](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Peptic_ulcers.html)) in adults when used in combination with standard medical treatments. [[21]](#_note-pmid14522098/) Antibiotic-associated diarrhea A meta-analysis suggested probiotics may reduce antibiotic-associated diarrhea. [[22]](#_note-pmid12182746/) A subsequent randomized controlled trial also found benefit in elderly patients. [[23]](#_note-pmid17604300/) Reducing Inflammation LAB foods and supplements have been found to modulate inflammatory and [hypersensitivity](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Hypersensitivity.html) responses, an observation thought to be at least in part due to the regulation of cytokine function. [[17]](#_note-Reid_Jass_Sebulsky/) Clinical studies suggest that they can prevent reoccurrences of [inflammatory bowel disease](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Inflammatory_bowel_disease.html) in adults, [[17]](#_note-Reid_Jass_Sebulsky/) as well as improve milk [allergies](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Allergies.html) [[24]](#_note-11/) and decrease the risk of [atopic eczema](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Atopic_eczema.html) in children. [[25]](#_note-12/) Improving Mineral Absorption It is hypothesized that probiotic lactobacilli may help correct malabsorption of trace minerals, found particularly in those with diets high in phytate content from whole grains, nuts, and legumes. [[26]](#_note-13/) Prevents Harmful Bacterial Growth Under Stress In a study done to see the effects of stress on intestinal flora, rats that were fed probiotics had little occurrence of harmful bacteria latched onto their intestines compared to rats that were fed sterile water. [[27]](#_note-14/) Irritable Bowel Syndrome and Colitis B. infantis 35624, sold as Align, was found to improve some symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome in women in a recent study. [[28]](#_note-15/) Another probiotic bacterium, Lactobacillus plantarum 299V, was also found to be effective in reducing IBS symptoms. [[29]](#_note-EurJGastroHepatol2001-Niedzielin/) Additionally, a probiotic formulation, VSL3, was found to be effective in treating ulcerative colitis [[30]](#_note-16/) Bifidobacterium animalis DN-173 010 may help. [[31]](#_note-pmid17635382/) Synbiotics It is also possible to increase and maintain a healthy bacterial gut flora by increasing the amounts of [prebiotics](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Prebiotic_%28nutrition%29.html) in the diet such as [inulin](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Inulin.html), raw [oats](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Oat.html), and unrefined [wheat](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Wheat.html).[citation needed] As probiotics are mainly active in the small intestine and prebiotics are only effective in the large intestine [[32]](#_note-Synbiotics/), the combination of the two may give a synergistic effect. Appropriate combinations of pre- and probiotics are synbiotics. Synbiotics have also been defined as metabolites produced by ecoorgan or by synergistic action of prebiotics and probiotics e.g. short chain fatty acids, other fatty acids, amino acids, peptides, polyamines, carbohydrates, vitamins, numerous antioxidants and phytosterols, growth factors, coagulation factors, various signal molecules such as cytokine-like bacteriokines.[citation needed] Types The most common form for probiotics are dairy products and probiotic fortified foods. However, tablets, capsules and sachets containing the bacteria in freeze dried form are also available. | Proven probiotic strains. Source:|[[33]](#_note-17/) | Strain || Brandname|| Producer || Proven effect in humans | 010 | coli](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Escherichia_coli.html) Nissle 1917 | || Rhodia Inc. || reduces symptoms of lactose intolerance, prevents bacterial overgrowth in small intestine | | Lactobacillus casei DN114-001 || diarrhoea, induces satiety, metabolizes || Yakult atopic eczema, prevents diarrhoea in children and many other Lactobacillus rhamnosus salivarius UCC118 || || || positive lactis against diarrhoea and |[Clostridium difficile](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Clostridium_difficile.html) infections; symptoms of intolerance | | tested as mixture:| Lactobacillus rhamnosus GR-1 & Lactobacillus reuteri RC-14 | ||Chr. Hansen|| Oral ingestion results in vaginal colonisation and prevention of vaginitis | | tested as mixture:| VSL#3 (mixture of 8 srains of Streptococcus thermophilus & spp & three Bifidobacterium spp strains | || || positive effects with intestinal ulcers and inflammation | | tested as mixture:| Lactobacillus acidophilus CUL60 & Bifidobacterium Cl. faeces | Rosell || prevents diarrhoea in children, prevents upset stomachs for patients on antibiotics.|[[39]](#_note-pmid8140765/), active against [Helicobacter pylori](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Helicobacter_pylori.html) Some commonly used bacteria in products, but without probiotic effect (yogurt bacteria): Some other bacteria mentioned in probiotic products: - Bacillus coagulans - Lactobacillus bifidus - became new genus Bifidobacterium - Lactobacillus caucasicus, a fantasy name, as no species with this name exists. Some fermented products containing similar lactic acid bacteria include: - Pickled vegetables [[40]](#_note-aeslab/), [[41]](#_note-fv/), [[42]](#_note-nmcd/) Fermented [[45]](#_note-labi/) - Tempeh [[46]](#_note-mamt/) - Zha cai[citation needed] Research A 2007 study at University College Cork in Ireland showed that a diet including milk fermented with [Lactobacillus](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Lactobacillus.html) bacteria prevented [Salmonella](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Salmonella.html) infection in pigs. [[47]](#_note-22/) A 2007 clinical study at Imperial College London showed that consumption of a probiotic drink containing L casei, L bulgaricus, and S thermophilus can reduce the incidence of antibiotic associated diarrhoea and C difficile associated diarrhoea. [[23]](#_note-pmid17604300/) Criticism Some mainstream researchers in Europe as well as in the United States are skeptical of some of the claims made for probiotics. Their reasons include the following considerations [[48]](#_note-23/): - The studies done in support of probiotics are mostly anecdotal or heavily reliant on test-tube experimentation rather than on clinical trials in human subjects - The basic concept of probiotics is based on a misunderstanding of the role of microflora in the human [digestive tract](https://www.bionity.com/en/encyclopedia/Digestive_tract.html). - It is difficult to see how bacteria taken by mouth can survive the process of human digestion (though research shows that they do, in fact, survive [[49]](#_note-24/)) References - [^](#_ref-FAO.2FWHO_0/) FAO/WHO (2001) Health and Nutritional Properties of Probiotics in Food including Powder Milk with Live Lactic Acid Bacteria.
